88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:19): 7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6, just because openness and standards work for the web doesn't mean they're needed everywhere.  I tend to broadly agree with Eric S. Raymond's analysis of open-source software, where he suggests that closed-source software will always work better in some markets.  The same logic applies to open standards.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:20): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, please elaborate. don't work ‚Äúclosed‚Äù products better even with open standards?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:21): Well, if interoperability is useful, yes.  What do games need to interoperate on?
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:21): There may be more people than h4kon advocating open standards while being perfectly fine with closed software.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:21): A typical high-end game is a standalone product that interacts with no other program (beyond the OS) and is basically obsolete in two years.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:22): What exactly is there to standardize?
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:22): Special clients? I always hated it when strategy games did not give me the ability to write my own macros.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:23): (The only one that included it was Earth2150 in 1999, but the current rights holder is opposed to releasing the source code.)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:23): What sort of API would they expose?  Different games work very differently, that's one of the problems.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:24): I just hate it when people lay bricks into my way of customizing things.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:24): I don't think standardization would help with that.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:24): Standardization is needed for inter-program APIs, document formats, things like that.  But any two independent games are different enough that there's nothing I can see that they could usefully share, in general.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:24): Well, they share things like graphics engines, clearly.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:25): But not along nice clean standardizable lines that you could make a stable API out of.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:25): They can be standardised at the OpenGL/DirectX level
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:25): At least it's my impression that when games use a third-party engine, they typically customize it to fit their needs.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:25): Well, yes.  Also file access can be standardized.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:25): Novel idea right there.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:25): But that's standardizing the OS, not the game.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:26): Anything higher-level will be obsolete within a year so everyone will want to write their own instead, unless the shared engine is continually updated and no longer standardised
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:26): Essentially, yes.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:27): (I've given thought to the possibility that an open-source graphics engine for games could be successful, if it used a dual-licensing scheme in the vein of MySQL.)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:27): (It's really ridiculous how companies rewrite their graphics engines from scratch for most games they make.)
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:27): Possible strawman: I neither do nor did advocate a common API or ABI for all games.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:28): (How would dual-licensing make it more successful than e.g. Ogre, which used to be dual-licensed and now is MIT?)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:29): 7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6, even similar games aren't similar enough that I see any useful API you could make.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:29): Maybe adopting a common scripting language or something like that, sure.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:29): Would be possible.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:29): LUA called, it wants its fame back ;)

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:30): But high-end games are usually written from scratch in a very short period and then thrown out.  That makes it unattractive to invest in features that aren't broadly useful.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:30): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, I've never heard of Ogre.  I'm just saying it could work, it could also fail for lots of reasons.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:30): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, re: dual-licensing ‚Äúcommercially successful‚Äù is different from ‚Äúbroad adoption successful‚Äù
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:31): My strategy would be to distribute it for free and let small players use it for free, and figure that if any big games stole it we'd notice.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:31): Try to get universities to use it in their courses, try to get a development community going.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:32): Anyway, I'm not actually going to try this, just an idle thought.
